intro: Drypetes alba var. alba, commonly known as white ghostwood, is a small to medium-sized evergreen tree native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Euphorbiaceae and is characterized by its smooth, pale bark and simple, opposite leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in clusters, followed by distinctive three-lobed capsules containing seeds. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often found in lowland forests and along riverbanks. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens and conservation areas.
